title: double-decker-bus-cafe-set-park-prestonpans
story: The proposals have been given the go-ahead by East Lothian Council, with the bus to be sited at the eastern end of Prestonpans, off the B.Matsform Ltd, the company behind the plans, told the local authority that the vehicle could be in a colour ldquosympathetically chosen to complement the coastal character of the site.According to the planning officerrsquos report: ldquoThe applicant has submitted a supporting statement that details how the proposed cafe would operate.ldquoIt advises that the proposed cafe would operate within the double-decker bus which is proposed to be sited within the John Muir Way car park for locals and visitors to enjoy.ldquoIt is indicated that the ground floor of the bus would contain a kitchen and one accessible table, with the upper floor of the bus used as a seating area with some  tables and four additional seats.ldquoThe agent indicates that the cafe would operate seasonally from am to pm Tuesday through Sunday from April to September, and from am to pm Wednesday through Sunday from October to March.ldquoThe bus will be positioned on the site at all times and would not be removed when not open for business.The proposals did not attract any comment from the townrsquos community council.One objection from the public focused on the potential of litter and waste from the proposed cafe.However, it was highlighted that matters relating to waste were not ldquomaterial considerations when it came to determining a planning application and would be tackled through other legislation.Planning permission has been given for one year to allow the council to ldquoassess the environmental impact of the development, while a planning condition stating that bins should be provided outside the bus at all times while trading has also been included.

title: hairdressers-scotland-reopen-week----changes-expect
story: Speaking in the Scottish Parliament on Thursday, the First Minister confirmed a number of lockdown measures would be eased across the country as we moved into Phase .She suggested that becuase of the drastic nature of the recent changes, it could be some time until we reach the final phase of the four-part route map out of lockdown.Among the eagerly anticipated dates announced for reopening - which generated laughter in Parliament - is that of hairdressers and barbers.Nicola Sturgeon confirmed this isfrom July .Personal retail services such as beauticians and tailors can reopen with enhanced hygiene measures can also reopen from July .Here, we outline some of the changes that will likely face you at the hairdressers:What changes will there be inside The British Beauty Council has outlined a number of suggested guidelines for social distancing and hygiene within hairdressers and salons.They suggest, among other advice, the following:Will I have to wear a mask According to the British Beauty Council, clients are to ldquobring their own PPE unless employers decide to supply.Currently, it looks like it will be a matter for each inidual salon to decide ndash but going on that advice it is probable you will have to wear a face covering.What  might change Some hairdressers may opt to extend their opening hours ndash meaning staff can see clients but have less people inside at any one time.As with supermarkets, the British Beauty Council recommends a ldquovulnerable hour first thing, once the salon has been deep cleaned from the previous day.It may also be harder to get an appointment, with extreme demand following lockdown and the need for an extra  minutes to be allocated for cleaning between clients.Many places will only allow pre-bookings, not walk-ins, and advance payments over the phone would be encouraged.Indoor waiting areas could also be scrapped, with customers having to wait outside until being called in at the time of their appointment.Will it cost more As expected, this might be the case.A note on the British Beauty Council website reads: ldquoIt may be advisable to raise prices to cover cost of PPE, longer opening hours, sanitisation and hygiene equipment, reduced appointments and other accrued costs as a result of COVID-.

title: joy-scottish-bookmakers-scottish-government-agrees-lift-restrictions-betting-shops
story: The shops were allowed to reopen their doors onJune  for the first time since the COVID- lockdown.But unlike in the rest of the UK, the shops were ordered to remove all of their chairs, switch off their gaming machines and not show any live racing on TV. chief executive Michael Dugher " alt"East Lothian Courier: Betting and Gaming Councilchief executive Michael Dugher " class"editor-image"Betting and Gaming Councilchief executive Michael Dugher As a result, turnover in some shops slumped by  per cent as customers either stayed away or crossed the border to England to put on a bet.Industry bosses warned that unless the restrictions were lted, shops could be forced to close and staff made redundant.Following a campaign by the Betting and Gaming Council, it has now been confirmed that from July , the restrictions will no longer apply.However, the shops will still follow strict anti-COVID measures, with customers being encouraged to apply sanitiser and follow social-distancing rules.BGC chief executive Michael Dugher said: ldquoThis is great news for Scotlandrsquos  betting shops and the , hardworking staff that they employ.ldquoWe have always said that the extra restrictions imposed on Scottish betting shops were unnecessary."We are delighted that the Scottish Government has listened and responded.ldquoBetting shops in Scotland can now look forward to playing their part in helping to kickstart the economy, supporting Scottish racing and providing a safe environment for customers who enjoy a flutter.

title: wetherspoons-slashes-pint-prices-1-29-reduces-cost-meals
story: The cuts were announced last week by the Chancellor Rishi Sunak in an attempt to ease economic pressures on the hospitality sector caused by the coronavirus pandemic and lockdown.VAT for the hospitality sector was cut from  per cent to five per cent, and Wetherspoons, who has a venue in Musselburgh, has said that it will pass the savings directly on to customers.Menus featuring a grinning Chancellor alongside messages labelled Sunaks specials and Dishi Rishi boast cut-price deals on food and drink with a pint of beer costing as little as pound..When will the deals start The deals will come into force from Wednesday, July , with real ale, coffee, soft drinks, breakfasts and other food among the discounted items.The VAT cut doesnrsquot apply to alcohol, but Wetherspoon has said it will cut the price of ales in reaction to savings made where.A pint of Ruddles Bitter now costs just pound., down from its pre-cut price of pound., while the price of a pint of Doom Bar has been slashed from pound. to pound..A traditional breakfast will cost pound. - a saving of p. A burger and soft drink is down to pound..Soft drinks will be cut by p, down to pound. for a oz glass.The deals will be in place at  of its pubs.Prices for real ale will be up to pound higher at the companyrsquos other  pubs across the UK which are located in major town and city centres, airports and stations.However, these pubs will have price reductions of at least  pence per drink and  pence per meal.What have Wetherspoons said Wetherspoon chairman Tim Martin called on the move to be made permanently.He said:"Wetherspoon has campaigned for tax equality between pubs, restaurants and supermarkets for many years. Supermarkets pay no VAT on food sales and pubs pay  per cent."Supermarkets pay about two pence per pint of business rates and pubs pay about  pence."These tax dferences have helped supermarkets to subsidise their selling prices of beer, wine and spirits, enabling them to capture about half of pubs beer sales, for example, in the past  years."A VAT reduction will help pubs and restaurants reverse this trend - creating more jobs, helping high streets and eventually generating more tax income for the Government."lsquoNeverspoonsrsquo appWetherspoons has been widely criticised during the coronavirus pandemic, particularly for Tim Martinrsquos actions regarding furloughing staff. An app launched in recent weeks advises pubgoers to avoid the high street chain.The Neverspoons app highlights local independent pubs close to Wetherspoon venues.App developer, Shane Jones, said:"The whole premise is, Wetherspoons is a massive chain and they dont need as much help.

title: three-simple-tips-stop-glasses-fogging-wearing-face-masks
story: Last week, the Scottish Government made it a legal requirement to wear coverings in shops - making the use of them a lot more widespread.It comes following the decision to make them mandatory on public transport - with the First Minister saying there has been "close to%" compliance with the new rules.But a number of Scots have been struggling to manage the masks, stating it causes their glasses to steam or fog up.Canny believe a need to pick between breathing or seeing pic VxpHumCgFollowing the latest move,Gordon Kyle fromof Miller and McClure Opticians in Paisley, shared his three top tips to avoid steaming up your lenses.He said: "Ive seen it a lot where peoples glasses are fogging up, there are a few things to think about".Here are the three tips:Mask behind glassesGordon suggests keeping the glasses on top of the mask, which acts almost as a seal keeping the mask tight to the top of the cheeks without pushing air towards the lenses.Tissue paperThe optician suggested lining the top of the mask with tissue paper before putting it on. In his video, this almost completely stops any fog taking place.Tie a knotGordons third tip was to tie the mask on the string so it sits "almost like a package". By doing this, the mask sits in a nicer shape where the air is being pushed away from the glasses.What  The optician joked that anyone with contact lenses should consider using them.Speaking to the Daily Record he also advised against lining the lenses with household items, as seen online.He said:ldquoThere has been chatonlineabout using shaving foam, toothpaste and even methylated spirits but my concern is that it could cause long term damage to the lenses.ldquoThe other thing folk have mentioned for the lenses is washing up liquid. Irsquom just not convinced that itrsquos risk free."

title: three-neighbours-scoop-1-000-peoples-postcode-lottery
story: The three residents of Cockenziersquos South Doors were announced as a daily prize winner with Peoplersquos Postcode Lottery this afternoon .Judie McCourt, Peoplersquos Postcode Lottery ambassador, sent her well-wishes to the winners, who have the postcode EH HR.She said: ldquoWhat great news for our winners today!ldquoCongratulations to them and I hope they get themselves a treat with their winnings.A minimum of  per cent of ticket sales goes directly to charities and players of Peoplersquos Postcode Lottery have raised more than pound million to date for thousands of good causes in Britain and beyond.This draw was promoted by Crisis, which has received more than pound. million in funding from the players of Peoplersquos Postcode Lottery.Crisis is dedicated to ending homelessness and helps about , people each year through education, housing, employment and health services across England, Scotland and Wales.Many good causes close to the winners have also benefitted from playersrsquo support, and local charities can next apply for funding in August.

title: town-centre-changes-go-ahead-north-berwick
story: East Lothian Council said public notices will go up tomorrowinforming residents and traders of plans to suspend parking on High Street for four hours on Thursday evening as works starts on its Spaces for People programme.The announcement comes less than a week after the local authority put plans to introducing parking restrictions in town centrs across the county on hold after they sparked an outcry from some traders.The council said that following a meeting with North Berwick Community Council and Coastal Area Partnership and town traders an agreement had been reached to introduce a number of temporary measures in the town, providing extra space for physical distancing to protect public health and suppress a resurgence of Covid-.Councillor Norman Hampshire, deputy council leader and environment spokesman said: "The work will focus on the narrow eastern section of North Berwick High Street and will provide the temporary widening of foothpaths to allow people walking, pushing prams or buggies or using wheelchairs to have sufficient space to observe the current m physical distancing guidelines."Some parking will be removed but a section will remain for local business use to support traders. In addition a combination of bollards and attractive planters will be introduced to narrow the road, reducing vehicle speeds and maximising pedestrian spaceldquoTo balance the need of businesses and supporting the local economy, parking provision within the town will be temporarily amended to provide spaces recognising in particular those with mobility needs."Additional Blue Badge spaces will be provided in Quality Street and Law Road car parks. We will also convert part of Elcho Green to a temporary car park to support access to the High Street area.High Street will be closed to through traffic and parking from .pm tomorrowevening until .pm.The work will be carried out in the following phases:Phase  ndash East End of High Street - Thursday, July ,  from . to .pm to place demarcation bollards and road markings to allow authorised vehicles only to park. Erection of signs re-designating Law Road car park to  minutes and St Andrew Street to  minutes with no .Open Elcho Green to long stay car parking Friday, July  . Barriers and cones to be placed to guide cars parking. Temporary signing of car parks to be erected.Phase  ndash High Street w c Monday, July ,all day rolling programme to conclude the introduction of demarcation bollards and changes to road marking and placement of signs including all link streets except Law road. Disabled bays to be marked out.Phase  ndash One way system from week commencing Monday, July  will mean temporary road works and localised disruption. Road marking and signage to make one way system including demarcation bollards on Law Road. Erection of timeplates to enforce restrictions.Phase  ndash Evening road closure High Street from week commencing Monday, August  to allow for placement of prefabricated speed cushions on High Street and the siting of a speed reactive sign.Application of rolling grasscrete system to protect Elcho Green.

title: helicopter-called-help-dunbar-rnli-crews-search
story: The towns leboats were tasked by UK Coastguard shortly after .pm following the report of someone in trouble in the water close to Dunbar Battery.A spokesman for the RNLI said: "Shortly after launching the crew of Dunbarrsquos Inshore Leboatsighted and made contact with three ers who were located within the search area."Unfortunately, the concerned member of the public who originally called the Coastguard was no longer in the area but Coastguard teams were able to make contact shore side and it was deemed that it was indeed the ers that the first responder had seen in the water."At this time a Coastguard Rescue Helicopter had arrived on scene and was performing a sweep of the area."The helicopter was able to confirm that no other casualties could be seen in the area."However, it was not just the ers that the RNLI crew was able to spot.As the helicopter performed its sweep, the all-weather leboat crewwas joined by a pod of dolphins who appeared keen to assist in the search.The spokesman added: ldquoOur thanks go to the discerning member of the public who showed no hesitation in calling for help when they saw someone in dficulty."On this occasion, it was a  alarm with good intent but we are offered a firm reminder of the inherent dangers of the sea.

title: decision-made-future-former-coastguard-station
story: The plans for the former coastguard base in Dunbar were rejected by East Lothian Councilrsquos planners amid concern about the lack of garden and amenity and living space.Judy Oxley, who is behind the proposal, and Sutherland and Co Architects Ltd, the agents, have appealed to the councilrsquos Local Review Body to overturn the decision.And in a supporting statement which will be presented to the body when it meets via Skype today , the agents challenge the concern over amenity.In their statement, they point out that the new home, on the townrsquos Lamer Street, will look out onto the beach, a point they said was made to planners at the time of the original application.They said: ldquoWe made the point that the proposal includes a balcony and ground to the rear for amenity. The site is also opposite the beach.Despite its proximity to the beach, planning officers ruled there was insufficient amenity.They also pointed out that the living space in the proposed bijou beach front home would give any occupant just nine square metres of living kitchen space.The plans to turn the station into a one-bedroom house were lodged after it went on the market for pound, when the emergency service moved to a new base where in the town.Plans lodged with the council proposed creating a living area downstairs and an upstairs bedroom with a balcony which would look out onto the sea.However, revised plans used part of the downstairs area for parking and cut the space available.A report by East Lothian Councilrsquos planning officer said: ldquoGiven the small area of the ground floor and that within that area the wet room and stairs would be provided, the actual living kitchen area of the house would amount to around nine square metres.The Local Review Body will meet to discuss the appeal this afternoon .

title: library-service-allowing-people-pre-order-books-returns
story: Plans to reopen some library services have been announced, with the first phase seeing an order and collect service launched in Haddington.East Lothian Council said people were able to go online or telephone the library, which is based in the John Gray Centre, from today to order books and arrange a time to collect them from Monday.Musselburgh Library is expected to follow suit early next month with a similar service on offer.People will be able tobooks to a collection box within the library during its opening hours however, they will not be able to browse shelves or use other library services such as wi-fi or printing facilities.Popular childrenrsquos activities and events will also not resume.Library staff are expected to begin toto other branches in the coming weeks to prepare their lending stock.Councillor Jim Goodfellow, the councilrsquos community wellbeing spokesperson, said: ldquoAlthough there will be no physical events or activities within the buildings, the library servicesrsquo online e-resources and social media engagement continues.ldquoLibrary services staff are as eager as everyone to see our libraries reopen and are looking forward to when we can welcome people back to these well-used community facilities but we need to respect current health guidelines.ldquoSafety of both public and staff remains our top priority, which means we have to have in place appropriate preventative measures against possible spread of Covid- and itrsquos important to emphasise that, whilst some library services will resume, this is not yet an opportunity toto lsquonormalityrsquo, with the service operating at a reduced level for some time to come to accommodate safety measures.Library borrowers will be able to order specic titles or a selection of items including books, DVDs, CDs and audio books, which they can then collect in person from the library up to a maximum of six per person.Only people who have arranged a collection will be able to visit the library at this stage.Orders can be made by emailing libraries@eastlothian.gov.uk, calling the council switchboard on   and asking for Haddington Library, or through Eventbrite at www.eventbrite e click-and-collect-at-haddington-library-tickets-Orders will be collected from Haddington Library at a booked time and date andbins will be available there and also at theBrunton Hall, MusselburghJohn Muir House, Haddington and Port Seton Community Centre, from Monday.Initial opening hours for collection times for Haddington Library at the John Gray Centre will be Monday to Friday am-pm and -.pm title: st-marys-minister-speaks-hard-time-church-closure
story: St Maryrsquos Parish Church announced it was reopening its doors, between set times, last week.The pandemic had seen the doors of the historic church closed since March, with members of the congregation instead able to view services online or by phoning a specic number.The Rev Alison McDonald has been minister at St Maryrsquos in Haddington for nearly a year.In the churchrsquos newsletter, she was pleased to say the building was now able to open its doors for small funerals and personal prayers for the first time in more than three months.She said: ldquoAlthough we know it has been necessary, having to close our church has been very hard and even more so while we have been living through such dficult times.ldquoIn all areas of le, however, itrsquos clear that emerging from lockdown is more complex than going into it this means that opening our church doors is not as simple as it sounds.ldquoA small team has been working very hard looking at the detailed guidance and comprehensive health and safety measures which we must put in place before opening and keep in place once we are open.ldquoWe are very fortunate in St Maryrsquos to have people who are able to do this.ldquoThis means that our doors are only open twice a week. The restricted times are due to the strict cleaning required and theof time we are advised to leave between each opening.A one-way system has been created in the church, with people entering by the north door and leaving by the west door.The church is now open -pm on a Sunday and -pm on a Wednesday, with people visiting asked to wear a face covering.Meanwhile, a recent Scottish Government announcement allowed churches to open for congregational worship from Wednesday.A statement on St Maryrsquos website says: ldquoThe task group will be considering the guidance with a view to making recommendations to our Kirk Session. This is likely to involve many decisions.ldquoAs always, the safety of our St Maryrsquos family is most important and the Kirk Session takes its responsibility of care very seriously.ldquoWe ask for your patience and understanding as we consider what needs to be done and also what our worshipping community needs to do to keep everyone safe.

title: dunbar-grammar-staff-get-bikes-support-former-pupil
story: Eric Fraser and Steven Elms, from the schoolrsquos PE department, were joined by Scott Marnoch, Active Schools co-ordinator at the school, and Paul Sutherland, the schoolrsquos principal teacher of health and wellbeing, in pedalling  miles around East Lothian earlier this month.The quartet wanted to show their support to champion kickboxer Fraser Riach-Shaw, who was diagnosed with Ewing sarcoma earlier this year.Paul told the Courier they were keen to support Fraser, who has raised more than pound, for Edinburgh Childrenrsquos Hospital Charity while undergoing treatment.He said: ldquoFraser is an ex-pupil and absolutely loved his PE.ldquoHe was a great lad within school and he was always really keen to be involved in sports.ldquoHe was part of the football team and contributed to that and is a mad football fan as well.ldquoHe is an all-round really lovely lad who was a joy to teach and he worked hard within the school.ldquoWe wanted to show our support and make him aware that we are behind him in this dficult time.Last month, staff at the school launched their own fundraising initiative to back Fraser, who lives in the town. lsquoDunbar to Troon in Junersquo ndash a distance of . miles ndash encouraged people from throughout the town to cover the distance by any form of exercise.Mr Sutherland, who has been a teacher at the school for the last five years, said the staff were keen to do their bit as well.He said: ldquoWhen I found out about Fraserrsquos diagnosis and I saw his posts and stuff online, I reached out to him to say: lsquoAs a school, we are thinking about you and here to support you in any way.rsquoldquoHe is that type of boy where he is really positive around the whole situation, which is a really dficult thing to do being so young and being diagnosed with cancer.The four teachers, who were joined by Thomas Salkeld, Haddington rugby development officer, for the last  miles, met in Haddington with a view to covering the distance throughout the day.Mr Sutherland, , said: ldquoWithin the first five minutes we were absolutely soaked to the bone.ldquoWithin the first  miles, we had our first puncture. That was coming into Musselburgh and I knew there was Aces Bike Co behind The Brunton. We walked Scottrsquos bike in and had to get a new tyre because it was blown to bits.ldquoThat was the only hiccup and the rest was plain sailing.The cycle was broken down into two loops, with the first taking in Haddington, Tranent, Wallyford, Musselburgh, Prestonpans and Dunbar before ing to Haddington. The second, smaller loop saw the quartet visit East Linton, Tranent and Macmerry before finishing back in Haddington.Mr Sutherland added: ldquoI know Eric is a pretty keen cyclist.ldquoHe was finding it alright but, for the other three of us, the last  miles were a bit of a challenge thatrsquos for sure. Our legs were a little bit sore the next day.To support Fraserrsquos campaign, go to gofundme f hta-a-cause-i-care-about-needs-help

title: community-resilience-efforts-cockenzie-port-seton-dunbar-gullane-haddington-musselburgh-north-berwick-prestonpans
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at six of the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Cockenzie and Port Seton. Picture: Google MapsCockenzie and Port SetonTHE resilience group in Cockenzie and Port Seton is starting to scale back its work as resilience groups begin to prepare for le after lockdown.The local effort has been led since March by Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council.Its chairman Bryan Hickman said a questionnaire was sent out to those it had helped and delivered meals to.The Port Seton Centre has been operating a meal delivery service for those in need.Meals have been cooked by council staff, assisted and delivered by resilience volunteers.The centre has also been offering a food hub for people to collect essential items.Recently, fruit and vegetables have been placed outside the centre for people to take and use.The questionnaire aimed to find out what people would like to do when lockdown finished.Sixty responses said that people wanted to continue a meals on wheels style service that they would pay for.Bryan said the community council was looking into this.He added: ldquoWe want to have some sort of legacy after lockdown finishes rather than just end it and that is it finished.He also said it would be a good idea to collect all of the ideas and how other parts of the county had delivered resilience efforts over the past four months, which, as well as allowing people to learn from each other, would allow efforts to start up again should they be needed.Bryan said the resilience effort would either stop at the end of the month or when children went back to school in August.He added: ldquoSo many people have contributed in so many ways, whether it be skills, money or food and donations.One helper at the start of the month was county Provost John McMillan, who delivered food to one elderly housebound resident.Contact detailsTo contact the Cockenzie and Port Seton resilience team, call  .DunbarDunbarCOMMUNITY resilience volunteers in Dunbar have had a quiet week.The group, which is split into a number of zones and also covers West Barns, was set up at the beginning of the coronavirus lockdown restrictions.George Robertson, who has been at the centre of the community resilience efforts, vowed they would continue to support people even as East Lothian moved from a response to a recovery phase.He told the Courier: ldquoOur volunteers continue to support our vulnerable regular customers, and will be on hand for future emergencies."Many are now ing to work or going on holiday, and are standing down from volunteer duties, but we still have a small core willing and able to help.One scheme that was launched in Dunbar was asking members of the public to donate laptops and tablets.The electronic devices would be wiped clean before being passed on to students from the townrsquos schools, who were working from home with the schools closed due to the coronavirus.George said the scheme had been a success.But, like calls for assistance, the number of items being donated had slowed down.He said: ldquoThe last of the laptops has now been delivered and I am not expecting any more donations."The totals stand at  devices collected, of which  were refurbished and passed on to the schools, with some tablets given to youth clubs."Our volunteers continue to support the foodbank and the meals service.Contact detailsTo contact the Dunbar resilience team, email Dunbar.covid@gmailGullane. Picture: Google MapsGullaneA FACILITY offering everything from hearing aid batteries to childrenrsquos toys and flour has shut up shop.Gullane Resilience Team has been running a village hall hub over the last  weeks, where people could exchange DVDs, books and more.The hard-working team of volunteers are getting ready to step back as lockdown restrictions are eased.The group highlighted some of the work that had been carried out over the last few months.Gordon McLelland, co-ordinator, said: ldquoDonated fabric was collected in the hub which helped the Gullane Scrubbers make hundreds of scrubs and scrub bags for the NHS, GPs, opticians and nursing homes, as well as face coverings for the community."They are now moving on to making surgical gowns for the Sick Kids ndash what an amazing bunch of sewers!"We wish to thank the community who kindly donated goods and money throughout the period, which has enabled us to make generous donations to the Village Hall, Muirfield Riding Therapy, Brain Tumor Research, East Lothian Foodbank and the Gullane Scrubbers."Cheques were presented by the volunteers to three of the charities on Sunday.The foodbank received a cheque for pound, while Gullane Village Hall was given a cheque for pound, and Muirfield Riding Therapy was given pound.Gordon also thanked Gullane Village Hall trustees for the use of the hall.He added his thanks to The Bonnie Badger, the villagersquos Co-op store and North Berwickrsquos Aldi store for their food donations.Thanks were also given to Gullane Parish Church and the resilience volunteers, in particular Lorna Scott.Contact detailsContact the team for help on   or by emailling gullanerteam@gmailHaddingtonHaddingtonFACE shields are being made for businesses throughout Haddington by the head of the townrsquos community resilience efforts.Chris McEwan, vice-chairman of the townrsquos community council, has coordinated the community resilience response in Haddington.He told the Courier that the need for volunteers to collect shopping and prescriptions had dropped in recent weeks as lockdown restrictions were eased.Now, attention has turned to making personal protective equipmentfor businesses which are reopening.Chris said: ldquoThings are getting quieter."We are still collecting prescriptions but we are letting people know that we are going to be stopping."We are going to be doing a handover to East Lothian Council at some point."We are still doing the lending library and I am doing more and more face shields for more and more businesses opening up."There are a lot of pubs and hairdressers and Irsquom doing face shields for them so that they have got PPE.Earlier in the lockdown, the community councillor worked alongside other members of the public to produce face shields for people working in the healthcare sector.Now, he is using his D printer to make them for local businesses.He described the scheme as ldquonot a huge amount of effort but a huge amount of gain.Organisations are not being charged for the PPE but instead are being asked to make a donation to local groups, such as Our Community Kitchen, the lending library or the community council.Chris added: ldquoWe want to make sure the money is going back into the community."I donrsquot want to charge businesses given the hassle that they have had but we are trying to keep the money locally."It is a good idea just to keep the community spirit going that we have built up over the last four months and to keep that running.Contact detailsAnyone needing assistance can call   between am and pm.Further information is available from haddingtoncc.org.ukMusselburgh. Picture: Google MapsMusselburghA GRADUAL decrease in calls for emergency support and referrals is being experienced by Resilient Musselburgh as the Covid- lockdown eases.Iain Clark, chairman of Musselburgh Area Partnership, said that,this trend continued, a gradual phased approach out of the emergency community response was planned over the next six weeks.The area partnership, along with Musselburgh  Inveresk Community Council, launched Resilient Musselburgh at the start of the crisis.Their efforts, supported by an army of local volunteers, ensured vulnerable people in the Musselburgh area, including Wallyford and Whitecraig, received aid such as food and medical supplies as well as activity packs and even books.Iain said: ldquoResilient Musselburgh continues to support the community as needed. As we move through the phases of easing lockdown, we can see a gradual decrease in calls for emergency support and referrals, which is what we would expect as peoplersquos circumstances change."We will continue to provide our response and support where real need is identied."It is important that Resilient Musselburgh reduces the emergency element of community response as the need reduces to ensure we can revert to lsquonormal businessrsquo for the Musselburgh area through our community councils and area partnership, who will continue to support the community as normal.He added: ldquoWe are grateful to St Andrewrsquos Church for their recent financial donation.Contact detailsGet in touch with Resilient Musselburgh on  .North Berwick.William Starkey and licensed for reuse under this Creative Commons LicenceNorth BerwickTHE final online consultation event organised by North Berwick Community Emergency Resilience Team is being held at am tomorrow.It is the last in a series of online events to get experiences and views about the way local people were helped during the Covid- crisis.These will be used to develop a new Community Emergency Response Plan for a new team to take over.Go to bit.ly etkATR to register for the webinar.An online survey at surveymonkey r DRXYHW is also still open.The resilience team is preparing to stand down at the end of the month.Meanwhile, North Berwick Day Centre has started organising hour-long sightseeing tours in its bus for members.Jenny Stephenson, an administrator and cook at the centre, said the bus was only taking one member at a time and they were accompanied by a member of staff on the trips, which are taking place three times a day.The bus is cleaned down after each trip.She said: ldquoThe trips have been organised to title: inside-scotlands-cinemas-post-lockdown----changes-need-know
story: Strict new social distancing and hygiene rules wereput in place to allow movie-lovers back in to the big screen from July .Our reporter took a trip to one Odeon theatre to see how cinemas are adapting to the new normal as lockdown continues to ease.Here are all the changes you should know about: Pre-booking is encouraged ndash and cash is outBooking your tickets online in advance is the Odeonrsquos preferred option, allowing you to pick up your tickets from machines in the foyer, minimising face-to-face contact.This was also strongly encouraged by the First Minister when she revealed plans to reopen cinemas and other indoor leisure.The ticket desk is still open for those who didnrsquot get the memo ndash but itrsquos important to remember that as with most things currently itrsquos strictly card only. Food and drink is still availableFor those whorsquove spent the last  months banking their furlough cash, the concessions are still open.Be aware that it too is card only and may take a little longer due to social distancing and hygiene regulations.Social distancing at a Showcase Cinema Masks are mandatory with one exceptionJust like at the shops, the chain has deployed staff members at the entrances to enforce mask-wearing and give directions.I didnrsquot notice any spare masks so be sure to bring your own.From the moment you enter you will be expected to keep your face covered, with one exception ndash when yoursquore at your seats within your safety lsquobubblersquo, you can feel free to remove your mask and shovel grub down your gob unabated. Social distancing is in ndash and seat reservations are outThe interior of the cinema has been redesigned with the typical arrows, stickers and temporary fences wersquove all gotten accustomed to.There are many minor changes ndash for example, staff will no longer take your tickets for inspection ndash but the most noticeable one is that staff will now chaperone you to your screen from the foyer and assign your seats in order to maintain a safe distance between groups.For the Odeon, this meant two seats apart within a checkerboard formation. Consequently, you can no longer reserve specic seats in advance, so itrsquos down to luck whether you end up with good seats or not. Itrsquos arguably better than everI was pleasantly surprised to realise that no longer did I run the risk of being seated next to any matter of unpleasant cinema-goers: chatty teens, habitually coughing oldies, or worst of all, those who insist on answering phone calls whilst in the theatre ndash all three of which Irsquom sorry to say Irsquove experienced before.And with barely any adverts running, and classic films such as Star Wars on show for cheap, the experience at the moment is arguably far better than it has ever been.Its cheaper, too. I paid pound. to see thriller Black Water: Abyss.

title: list-glasgow-shops-administration-lockdown
story: Here we look at some of the businesses who will no longer be operating in the city and the ones under threat.Remnant KingsCity location: Howard StreetA total of  stafflost their jobs from the firmrsquos bases in Glasgow, Hamilton, and Edinburgh after the administrators were called in.The firm, which started in Glasgow in , said that although they were historically profitable, they have since suffered from declining turnover and trading dficulties in recent years caused by changing consumer habits.:Glasgow firm Remnant Kings goes into admistration resulting in job lossesOasis and Warehouse GroupCity locations past and present: Buchanan Galleries, Silverburn, Princes Square, and Glasgow Fort.The company behind Oasis and Warehouse went into administration in April when Deloitte was appointed as administrator.All stores haveclosed indefinitely whileonline sales have stopped.Reports say the fashion brands have been sold to restructuring business Hilco in a deal which includes stock but not the  stores or  concessions.Hash Ladha, chief executive of Oasis Warehouse, previouslysaid: ldquoThis is a situation that none of us could have predicted a month ago, and comes as shocking and dficult news for all of us.ldquoWe as a management team have done everything we can to try and save the iconic brands that we love.:Oasis and Warehouse who have shops in Glasgow fall into administrationCath KidstonCity location: Gordon StreetCath Kidston said they will not reopen their shops when lockdown ends.They called in the administrators in April with the closure of shops costing around  jobs.It is understood that the owner of the retro fashion brand has secured a deal to buy back the brand and its online operation. jobs are on the line after the UK arm of retailer Victorias Secret collapsed into administration.Around  stores are at risk after the lingerie retailer called in Deloitte for a light touch administration after being hit by the closure of stores during thecoronaviruscrisis.InScotland, the brands flagship store is on Glasgows Buchanan Street, meaning jobs within the city centre are at risk.The store in Buchanan Street opened in  in the place of Buchanan Galleries former HM premises, after previously opening a shop in Glasgow Airport in .MonsoonCity locations: Silverburn and store leases.He will hope to save as many as  stores and , jobs.The firm announced the news in June.:Monsoon enters administration threatening over  job lossesQuizCity locations:Buchanan Street, St  staff affected by the decision will remain with the group but that  jobs are at risk.Quiz will look to buy back the stock and some of the assets from the Kast ision placed in administration for
